desc: SF3B1 encodes a component of the spliceosome complex that is involved in mRNA processing. Mutations in SF3B1 lead to aberrant alternative splicing and altered gene expression.

The SF3B1 (splicing factor 3b subunit 1) gene encodes a protein in the spliceosome complex that is responsible for removal of introns from messenger RNA. SF3B1 is an essential gene/protein so loss is not tolerated in cells, therefore very few if any truncating mutations or SF3B1 gene loss/deletions are observed. This complex contains snRNAs (small nuclear RNAs), snRNP (small nuclear ribonucleoprotein particles) and non-snRNP proteins. SF3B1 binds to nucleosomes to identify exon and intron junctions of coding genes (PMID: 25892229). SF3B1 also contributes to sister chromatid cohesion and chromosome segregation (PMID: 25257310). Mutations in SF3B1 are recurrent in uveal melanoma (PMID: 26842708). Additionally, mutations in SF3B1 are frequent in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) (PMID: 21909114, 21995386), especially those with refractory anemia with ring sideroblasts (RARS) and refractory cytopenia with multilineage dysplasia and ring sideroblasts (RCMD-RS) (PMID: 21995386, 21998214). Mutations in SF3B1 lead to altered gene expression and aberrant alternative splicing (PMID: 25428262). mRNAs can become mis-spliced by use of alternative or non-canonical splice sites or may retain introns leading to altered coding sequences (PMID: 25768983, 22150006). Mutations in SF3B1 tend to occur in the C-terminal HEAT repeat region and tend to be missense mutations rather than non-sense or frameshift mutations, suggesting that either gain-of-function, dominant negative or altered function results rather than complete loss of function (PMID: 22150006, 21909114). Mutations in SF3B1 are often mutually exclusive with mutations in other splicing factor mutations, including SRSF2, U2AF1, ZRSR2, SF1, PRPF40B, U2AF2 and SF3A1 (PMID: 21909114). The SF3B complex can be inhibited by naturally occurring compounds, including spliceostatin A (PMID: 17643111), meayamycin B (PMID: 23485022) and pladienolide (PMID: 17643112).
